Thanks. Just a question on Nigeria. You acquired the 3.7 million hectoliter breweries. Were they idle or were they producing? And could you give some clarity on how that would impact your business?
I visited Nigeria just last week, Nico. So I visited three out of the five breweries, and they were all producing. So a first witness. The Sonar group is --

So you said in your press release that you bought 3.7 million hectoliters, which gives you 3.7 million hectoliters additional capacity. So my question was, is this spare capacity or is this actually additional volumes?
No, there is part of additional volumes and there is part of spare capacity.
Okay.

I don't have this numbers top of mind, what's written in the – but normally it's half-half. What I've seen in Nigeria last week, these are breweries which are turning half of their capacity, and the one more than other, but that is roughly the thing. The second opportunity it gives, the extension possibilities in those five breweries at least in three of them are really pretty good. So things like the brew house can do the double, you just have to add things and this kind of thing.

So we can be pretty quick in expanding the capacity even beyond the 3.7. That is what it offers and you have to still realize, Nigeria has a proper infrastructure. I've seen much worse in Africa than in Nigeria, but it's not optimal, right? So it is not China where you have big roads and everything is very well arranged. So it's a little bit like Brazil, you need a little bit more plans and that offers us a better footprint for us to operate going forward in that country.
The profitability currently of business as you bought it, I presume is much lower than your existing business since the -?
Yes. You presume well.
Yeah.
So you should look at -
A serious question to Jean-François. So this is a big potential for Nigeria, this acquisition? And-

Yeah, it is. Look, for us, it was the choice of building an extra greenfield plant or even two plants or three plants and that costs you a lot of time. Of course, you start from a technologic and productivity base which will be better when you have built it, but in order to get there, you need to two to three years. Here, we have bottom in there immediately to be upgraded and yielding that additional capacity that we need.

So on the one hand, they will continue to do some of their local brands, which we value and which are good, well-positioned economy local brands and a part of the capacity will be used for all the products of the brands which are by nature, positioned higher in the market of Nigerian breweries and also part of consolidated breweries.
You did not disclosed the price the price that you paid?
No, we didn't.
Okay. And who was the shareholder of the two holding companies that you bought it from?
Did we disclose that?
No, I don't think so.
No, we don't, but --
It wasn't the government.

No, no, it wasn't the government. It's a private entrepreneur in Nigeria, a man who we are in business with. He is a supplier of us also. So we know who we buy it from. We have been doing proper due diligence. And we have taken over the company, it was last week there. I think it's a pretty good company with very motivated personnel and they make good quality beers. So, yeah, I'm looking forward to it.
Good.
Yeah, okay. One more question? I feel it's time for a beer.

I'm sorry, just a follow-on to my previous question. If you strip out the wholesale business in Western Europe, would you say that your beer margins are close to mid-teens? And just the second one, if you could just expand a bit on the contingent liability in Brazil, which is, I think, it's EUR1.2 billion of which for EUR306 million, you have to put on some guarantees, because it's related to tax. But there is a guarantee from – you have a clawback from FEMSA against that. But on the other EUR900 million, could you just explain a bit what is that about and if there could be any kind of coming out of there or a big surprise? Thanks.

On Brazil, indeed for the tax claims, we are fully indemnified by FEMSA and then there are a number of other claims. For those who know Brazil, it's a country which is very good in claiming. We have very thoroughly assessed all these claims and taken the right provisions, which is in no comparison with the nominal amount of the claim. And we feel pretty confident in the assessment we have given to it. That was Brazil.

First question was on the margins in Europe and I think we discussed it at half year as well. We have EUR2.4 billion turnover in wholesale, with a typical wholesale margin, even a bit below what is normally in some of the wholesales, who have the full portfolio. So that has a very low EBIT margin and you can subtract that.

That is the real figure of 2010 in Western Europe, so Waverly is half of it out, so you have to subtract another EUR200 million. So that is in our figures, so if you want to do the math on 2010, and there will be another EUR200 million going out of that for the first half of next year. Time for a beer?
Thank you.
Thank you.
